input: Share GitHub repo: free LLM course. P.S. Shoutout upcoming AI Builders Cohort
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose and Audience
- Purpose: Share a free LLM (Large Language Model) course hosted on GitHub; promote the value of open learning resources. Soft promotion of the upcoming "AI Builders Cohort."
- Audience: Aspiring AI engineers, developers interested in LLMs, and audience considering joining Shaw's future cohorts or learning journeys.

Step 2: Wireframe
- Hook: Flag there's a free practical LLM course for anyone who wants to get hands-on. 
- Meat: Briefly describe the repo, emphasize it’s free, and how it can help. Mention that you’re sharing because high-quality open resources still matter.
- CTA: Invite readers to check out the repo and share other open LLM resources they love.
- P.S.: Shoutout for AI Builders Cohort

Step 3: Body
- There’s a free, practical LLM course available on GitHub. 
- It covers the end-to-end workflow of building with large language models, hands-on and open to all.
- I’m always on the lookout for beginner-friendly, actionable resources—this one stood out as a solid foundation if you want to get started (or deepen your skills) with LLMs.
- Link to the repo

Step 4: CTA
- What other free LLM resources have you found valuable?

Step 5A: Brainstorm Hook Directions
1. [Open resource angle] - “A free way to get practical with LLMs, no paywall, no fluffy hype.”
2. [Beginner-friendly] - “Wish there was a hands-on LLM course (that didn’t cost $$$)?”
3. [Community contribution] - “The best AI courses aren’t always on paid platforms.”
4. [Trend/urgency] - “2024 is the year of the open LLM curriculum.”

Step 5B: Notes
- [Open resource] highlights value, access, no gatekeeping.
- [Beginner-friendly] hits pain point for newcomers—signal usefulness to those just getting started.

Step 5C: Final Hook
- “Not all the best LLM courses live behind a paywall.”

Step 6: Draft Post
Not all the best LLM courses live behind a paywall.

There’s a practical, beginner-friendly LLM course that’s 100% free and open on GitHub.

It covers the basics of building with large language models—starting from scratch, with hands-on code and real projects.

I’m sharing it because high-quality open resources still matter (and too often, they’re hard to find amid the noise).

Check out the repo here:
[GitHub link]

What other free LLM resources have you found valuable?

P.S. If you want to go even deeper, keep an eye out for my upcoming AI Builders Cohort. More details soon!

Step 7: Review
- Only one em dash (in “starting from scratch—”) and used intentionally.
- No repeated phrases. The hook and body are not redundant.
- CTA is singular: What other free LLM resources have you found valuable?
- Tone is factual, approachable, and clear.
- P.S. properly includes only a shoutout to the AI Builders Cohort.

Step 8: Final Post
final_post:
